text: I was the commander of sts-124 to the
role of the commander is to fly the
space shuttle if needed on a scent
usually it's not that would be an
emergency the biggest flight
responsibility of all is landing you
don't get a second chance you have to
make a good landing on the first try
four three two one booster ignition and
liftoff of discovery
right after liftoff there are a few
critical steps you have to reach out and
actually throw a switch so that you can
interpret the attitude control system
correctly that all has to happen in the
first few seconds there are updates
coming constantly from Mission Control
telling you how far along in the
trajectory you are and then the main
engines cut off and you're in zero-g
and your stomach says excuse me what was
that all about
and that's when pencils start to float
and cables start to float and you
realize your face that whole process is
eight and a half minutes discovery on
the big loop you have a go for docking
the mission of sts-120 was primarily to
deliver node two known as Harmony the
hub of all the International Laboratory
sections the relationship between the
commanders is actually very important to
set the tone for how the crews interact
Peggy Whitson who was the commander of
the space station at the time had been
on the space station when I came up on
my second flight we got to know each
other pretty well I was very excited to
see her because I knew that we knew how
to work together I was really looking
forward to shaking hands with Peggy
through the space station hatch and this
took on an enormous significance because
it was the first time two women
commanders had flown in space together I
think when you ask people about their
experiences as especially as a shuttle
astronaut that people just reflect on
the people that they were with and the
closeness that they felt to them and
that wonderful feeling of coming
together as a team and doing something
hard together
you
